timeline.message:
Generate javadocs for loader

Signed-off-by: liach <liach@users.noreply.github.com>
Add jd for all exposed classes
use readme as overview if pandoc generates one readme html

timeline.bodyText: This might not be the right place for this, as it can be diffrent for diffrent langs
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,7 +16,29 @@ package net.fabricmc.api; +/** + * A mod initializer ran only on {@link EnvType#CLIENT}. + * + *

This entrypoint is suitable for setting up client-specific logic, such as rendering + * or integrated server tweaks.

+ * + *

In {@code fabric.mod.json}, the entrypoint is defined as: + * 


+ *     "entrypoints": {
+ *         "client": [
+ *             <a list of string referring to your client mod initializers>

replies.bodyText: should make it entrypoint list notation instead, I guess?
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: People can just look at the docs on getEntrypointContainers, I think.
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: this doesnt seem great, no idea why they need the launcher meta json here.
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,7 +16,35 @@ package net.fabricmc.api; +/** + * Represents a type of environment. + * + *

A type of environment is a jar file in a Minecraft version's json file's {@code download} + * subsection, including the {@code client.jar} and the {@code server.jar}.

+ * + * @see Environment + * @see EnvironmentInterface + * @see A list of Minecraft + * version's json files + */

replies.bodyText: Just a reference for people for json so they can actually see the client/server sections in downloads section.
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: This isnt quite right I dont think, as its based on the implimentation
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,6 +16,87 @@ package net.fabricmc.loader.api; +/** + * Creates instances of objects from custom notations. + * + *

It enables obtaining of other JVM languages' objects with custom instantiation logic.

+ * + *

A language adapter is defined as so in {@code fabric.mod.json}: + * 


+ *   "languageAdapter": {
+ *     "<a key>": "<the binary name of the language adapter class>"
+ *   }
+ *
+ * Multiple keys can be present in the {@code languageAdapter} section.

+ * + *

In the declaration, the language adapter is referred by its binary name, + * such as {@code "mypackage.MyClass$Inner"}. It must have a no-argument public constructor for the Loader to instantiate.

replies.bodyText: 🤔 well, this is the technical name of the "dot format"
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: no, the 2nd bit about the constructor
replies.author: modmuss50

replies.bodyText:
Hmm, no? 
  
    
      fabric-loader/src/main/java/net/fabricmc/loader/FabricLoader.java
    
    
         Line 347
      in
      9f6b859
    
    
    
    

        
          
           adapterMap.put(laEntry.getKey(), (LanguageAdapter) Class.forName(laEntry.getValue(), true, FabricLauncherBase.getLauncher().getTargetClassLoader()).getDeclaredConstructor().newInstance()); 
        
    
  


Here loader is explicitly requiring calling the constructor
replies.author: liach

timeline.bodyText: I dont get everyone obession with using enums for singletons, lets not use it as an example.
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,6 +16,87 @@ package net.fabricmc.loader.api; +/** + * Creates instances of objects from custom notations. + * + *

It enables obtaining of other JVM languages' objects with custom instantiation logic.

+ * + *

A language adapter is defined as so in {@code fabric.mod.json}: + * 


+ *   "languageAdapter": {
+ *     "<a key>": "<the binary name of the language adapter class>"
+ *   }
+ *
+ * Multiple keys can be present in the {@code languageAdapter} section.

+ * + *

In the declaration, the language adapter is referred by its binary name, + * such as {@code "mypackage.MyClass$Inner"}. It must have a no-argument public constructor for the Loader to instantiate.

+ * + *

The {@code default} language adapter from Fabric Loader can accepet {@code value} as follows: + *

    + *
  • A fully qualified reference to a class, in + * binary name, such as {@code package.MyClass$Inner}, where the class has a public no-argument constructor + * and {@code type} is assignable from the class. + * + *

    An example of an entrypoint class + * 

    
+ *     package net.fabricmc.example;
+ *     import net.fabricmc.api.ModInitializer;
+ *     public class ExampleMod implements ModInitializer {
+ *       {@literal @}Override
+ *       public void onInitialize() {}
+ *     }
+ *
    + * You would declare {@code "net.fabricmc.example.ExampleMod"}.

    + * + *

    For each entrypoint reference, a new instance of the class is created. + * If this class implements two separate entrypoints, there will be two distinct + * instances of this class in two entrypoint containers.

    + *
    • + * + *
  • A fully qualified reference to a class in binary name followed by {@code ::} and a + * field name. The field must be static, and {@code type} must be assignable from + * the field's class. + * + *

    An example of an entrypoint field + * 

    
+ *     package net.fabricmc.example;
+ *     import net.fabricmc.api.ModInitializer;
+ *     public enum ExampleMod implements ModInitializer {
+ *       INSTANCE;

timeline.bodyText: are you sure? I have a feeling its /
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -21,63 +21,67 @@ /** * Helper class for performing mapping resolution. * - * Note: The target namespace (the one being mapped to) for mapping (or the + *

Note: The target namespace (the one being mapped to) for mapping (or the * source one for unmapping) is always implied to be the one Loader is - * currently operating in. + * currently operating in.

+ * + *

All the {@code className} used in this resolver are in binary names, + * such as {@code "mypackage.MyClass$Inner"}.

replies.bodyText: I think it is / as always used in mappings, but the old doc says it is dot format (see changeset below)
replies.author: liach
liach

timeline.bodyText: I think this fails to load with theses. Not sure if theses really need to say what loader does?
timeline.author: modmuss50
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -16,52 +16,129 @@ package net.fabricmc.loader.api.metadata; -import com.google.gson.JsonElement; -import net.fabricmc.loader.api.Version; - import java.util.Collection; import java.util.Optional; +import com.google.gson.JsonElement; + +import net.fabricmc.loader.api.Version; + +/** + * The metadata of a mod. + */ public interface ModMetadata { + /** + * Returns the type of the mod. + * + *

The types may be {@code fabric} or {@code builtin} by default.

+ * + * @return the type of the mod + */ String getType(); // When adding getters, follow the order as presented on the wiki. // No defaults. + /** + * Returns the mod's ID. + * + *

A mod's id must have only lowercase letters, digits, {@code -}, or {@code _}.

+ * + * @return the mod's ID. + */ String getId(); + + /** + * Returns the mod's version. + */ Version getVersion(); + /** + * Returns the mod's required dependencies, without which the Loader will terminate loading. + */ Collection getDepends(); + + /** + * Returns the mod's recommended dependencies, without which the Loader will emit a warning. + */ Collection getRecommends(); + + /** + * Returns the mod's suggested dependencies. + */ Collection getSuggests(); + + /** + * Returns the mod's conflicts, with which the Loader will terminate loading. + */ Collection getConflicts(); + + /** + * Returns the mod's conflicts, with which the Loader will emit a warning.

replies.bodyText:
https://fabricmc.net/wiki/documentation:fabric_mod_json?s[]=conflicts
Probably should say what loader does here.
